With the expansive information available online, it is becoming increasingly rare to chance upon a place that is unexpectedly charming! But every once in a while we travel to a country that leaves us smitten ‚Äì our trip in Bhutan was one such adventure! From the moment we landed till the moment we left, I was left marvelling at the sheer stature of the landscapes, the peace of the surrounding, and the happiness on the faces of Bhutanese people! After having travelled extensively in India, we were thrilled at the prospect of visiting its beautiful neighbouring country.

Here is everything you need to know about planning the ideal trip to Bhutan :-

Druk Air flies directly from Delhi to Paro a couple of times every week. We suggest planning your trip in a way that allows you to opt for these direct flights as they are very convenient. It was our first time flying with Druk Air and the service and aircraft both were above expectation! The best part about this flight are the scenic vistas as you land at Paro Airport ‚Äì so don‚Äôt forget to reserve a window seat for yourself! (left side when travelling from Delhi to Paro and right side on return :-)). We suggest comparing prices and booking here.

Bhutan is an ideal destination to visit year round, except for the months of June-August due to monsoons. Try to coordinate your visit with a local festival ‚Äì most festivals happen during September but others are spread throught the year. We travelled in the month of December and had a great time.

There are countless things to do in Bhutan and we‚Äôve tried to include as many as possible in our guide, but here are a few that you MUST not miss:

Bhutan prides itself on being one of the few carbon negative places in the world. The emphasis on sustainability and the happiness index means that there are rather strict guidelines that discourage mass tourism in the country! For eg it is compulsory for all tourists to have a 24X7 local guide in the country. For this reason, it is best to book the entire trip with 1 hotel chain that can offer a package that includes visas (for nationalities that need it), guide, hotel rooms, experiences, transportation, and all meals. We booked our entire trip with Six Senses Bhutan and cannot recommend the experience enough. You‚Äôll be pampered from the pickup at the airport to the drop off, that is for sure üôÇ

Indian nationals do not need a visa to enter Bhutan, however they are required to have travel insurance for the duration of the trip, a booking at a government enlisted property, a tour guide, and have to pay a Sustainable Development Fee (SDF) of INR 1200 per person per night. All details can be found on this link.

The local currency of Bhutan is Ngultrums, but Indian rupees are widely accepted. 1 BTN = 1 INR (as of Jan 24).

Now that the logistics are out of the way, let‚Äôs go over a day-by-day itinerary, including places and experiences that you definitely need to plan the perfect trip in Bhutan.

Paro Airport is a gorgeous building and offers the perfect introduction to Bhutan. Meet your guide as you exit the airport after passing through immigration and luggage collection and drive to your hotel.

We stayed at Six Senses Thimphu, also known as the Palace In The Clouds. Of all the hotels we stayed in Bhutan, this is one of the most beautiful! Situated high above the valley floor, overlooking apple orchards and young pine forests, with gorgeous views of the Buddha Dordemna, Six Senses Thimphu is the perfect base for exploring Thimpu and kickstarting your trip in Bhutan.

If you can tear yourself away from the incredible views at this hotel, spend the evening enjoying a Jet Lag or Deep Tissue Massage followed by a healing Dotsho bath ‚Äì this treatment is something you must not miss in Bhutan as it is a wellness ritual that uses hot stones and is known to cure joint pains and aches. One thing is for sure ‚Äì it will leave you truly relaxed and rejuvinated for all your adventures in Bhutan

On day 1, we suggest dining at Namhkha, the hotel‚Äôs signature restaurant that offers an array of Bhutanese and continental dishes.



Set aside Day 2 for exploring Thimphu Valley including Buddha Point, Memorial Chorten & its local markets

After breakfast, depart for Changangkha Temple, a sacred pilgrimage site overlooking Thimphu Valley. From here drive towards the iconic 52-meter-tall Buddha Dordenma. This is one of the highlights of the perfect trip to Bhutan. Once you have taken in the sheer size of the Buddha, step inside and discover the 125,000 smaller Buddhas inside (photography is not permitted inside).

Afterwards join Thimphu residents as they pray at the Memorial Chorten. Take in the hustle bustle of Thimphu and if you‚Äôre not tired, try visiting the Folk Heritage Museum, Zorig Chusom, (The National Institute for 13 Arts & Crafts) and the National Textile Museum. You can also visit a local paper making or incense making workshop.

Alternatively you‚Äôre in the mood for a hike, request your hotel to arrange one to Talakha Goemba situated on a ridge at 3,050 m. Rarely visited, this monastery boasts some of the best views of Thimphu Valley. This hike takes approximately 2 hours but is well worth it. On the way down stop at Lungsigang, a charming picnic spot for late afternoon tea and some energy boosting Bhutanese sweets and snacks.

After breakfast in Thimphu, begin your 2.5 hour journey towards Punakha. But make sure you stop en-route at Dochula Pass. On clear days, this pass offers stunning views of the Himalayan range. Take your time admiring the 108 chortens and walk around.

We planned our visit in a way that would allow us to experience one of Bhutan‚Äôs most iconic festivals at Dochula Pass ‚Äì Druk Wangyul gave us the perfect opportunity to experience the rich colors and traditions of Bhutan. This festival, is held in honor of Bhutan‚Äôs fourth king. Apart from the traditional singing and dancing which takes place here, one of the most outstanding features of this special occasion is the scenic beauty of the panoramic Himalayan range which acts as a backdrop for the colourful costumes displayed at the festival.

Gradually the landscape changes to a lush and subtropical valley with charming farmhouses and terraced rice fields. Stop as you enter the valley for a stroll across the rice paddies to Chimi Lhakhang, a fertility temple, to learn about Drukpa Kinley, the revered ‚ÄòDivine Madman‚Äô. The adjacent village has some surprisingly graphic phallic paintings to honor the saint on its homes and shops ‚Äì a truly unique pitstop!

Check in at Six Senses Punakha‚Äôs also known as ‚ÄòFlying Farmhouse‚Äô, as it is home to a unique floating wooden structure that serves as the lodge lounge and reception and offers gorgeous views over the pool and surrounded rice fields. Each of the spacious rooms offer incredible views of the valley and an open-plan living situation with floor to ceiling windows that makes one feel at one with nature.

Enjoy the views and if you‚Äôre in the mood for a bit of exercise in the evening we suggest a hike alongside the river climbing up to Khamsum Yulley Namgyel Chorten, a temple built by the Queen Mother to bring peace to the world. Just a short drive from Punakha Dzong, it takes about 50 minutes to climb from the road through beautiful, terraced rice paddies to reach the chorten which was completed in 1999 after eight years of construction. The visitor is rewarded with stunning views of the valley below just as the sun begins to set.



Wake up early for yet another highlight of this amazing trip to Bhutan! Visit a local monastery, that has been adopted by Six Senses, to join the cutest young monks for a traditional monastic breakfast. Afterwards, spend some time learning more about their lifestyle and sharing a simple breakfast with them.

In the afternoon, cross the country‚Äôs longest suspension bridge on foot before visiting the gorgeous Punakha Dzong, one of Bhutan‚Äôs most impressive landmarks. Located at the confluence of two rivers, Punakha Dzong is six stories high. Take your time to explore this architectural wonder with gorgeous courtyards, murals, and its prayer rooms. Make sure you take lots of photographs as this is a place you‚Äôll want to remember.

Afterwards, experience something truly luxurious if you are staying at Six Senses Punakha! You can catch the sun set over Punakha Dzong as you sip on pomegranate martinis,experience and enjoy light snacks in a rice field with a rushing river as your backdrop. We would highly recommend booking the Pomegranate Martini experience if you are celebrating a special ocassion or planning to propose. It provides the perfect backdrop!

Finally it‚Äôs time to leave Punakha. Paro is a 4 hour drive away. Enroute, you can stop at Rinpung Dzong and The Paro National Museum which displays a fascinating collection of Bhutanese relics. Make sure you walk along the busy streets of the town to explore the local handicraft scene or visit the colorful fresh market. You can also visit one of the colourful karaoke bars for a spot of fun!

From the town it‚Äôs a 20-minute drive up a high mountain road past stunning views of the valley below to the lodge. Six Senses Paro is situated at an elevation of 9,415 ft (2,870 m.) and offers amazing views of the surrounding area! We suggest spending a relaxing evening at the hotel trying local Bhutanese costumes (a kira and a gho) and trying your hand at archery, Bhutan‚Äôs national sport. This is great fun

Have a relaxed dinner at the hotel‚Äôs cosy and scenic restaurant Jangkho. The food here in absolutely scrumptious ‚Äì don‚Äôt forget to try local specialities like momos and Ema Datshi, a hearty Bhutanese curry with chillies. You can also take a momo making class here at the restaurant if you‚Äôre interested!

Set out early this morning on a challenging full day hike to Taktsang Goemba, more famously knowns as Tiger‚Äôs Nest. The hike begins at the base camp in a forested ridge and you will have to climb to an elevation of 2,950 meters. One of the most significant cultural icons of the Kingdom, the highly revered monastery was built on a sheer cliff face above Paro and is visible from the valley floor. During cooler weather clouds can shroud the monastery, highlighting its sanctity and remoteness.

Your guide will share stories of the monastery‚Äôs history along the way. Pine forests decorated with moss and prayer flags surround you as you make your way along the paths of this sacred trail. Hang prayer flags and wish upon the wind. The hike is fairly challenging and takes approximately 4-5 hours. But it is well worth the effort

If you‚Äôre not tired, visit Kyichu Lhakang, a 7th century sanctuary located nearby and one of the oldest religious structures in the Kingdom. An absolute gem for history buffs and architecture enthusiasts alike, it is said to have two magical orange trees that bear fruit throughout the year.

As you return to the hotel after the hike, make sure you relax by heading to the sauna or booking yourself another hot-stone massage to make the aches and pains go away.



Spend your last day in Bhutan learning how to make the Prayer Flags that you‚Äôve seen everywhere in the country! You can book this experience directly at your hotel. Drive to the home of a local family that has been making prayer flags by hand for generations. Learn the secrets of their craft and make your own prayer flags before a hearty lunch of local favorites.

Wrap up your trip with a Butter Lamp Blessing. We visited the tiny 16th century Samtenling Monastery, just a ten-minute walk from our hotel. Here there are no tourists ‚Äì we lit 108 butter lamps, believed to dispel darkness in the Universe, and this was followed by a blessing led by the resident monks. It was a uniquely spiritual end to our trip in Bhutan

This is the perfect itinerary for a week-long trip in Bhutan. However if you have a few more days, we also suggest adding Gangtey and Bumthang to your itinerary of Bhutan as well. If you have any questions regarding Bhutan, leave them below and we‚Äôll get back to you as soon as possible üôÇ



Doha, the shimmering capital of Qatar, is a city of striking contrasts‚Äîwhere futuristic skylines meet time-honoured souqs, and luxury lifestyle mingles with deep-rooted tradition. This 4-day guide will walk you through an elevated and thoughtfully curated itinerary, featuring beach clubs, dhow cruises, cultural landmarks, and glamorous shopping districts ‚Äì perfect for a refreshing city break.

Doha is well connected to most major cities in the world and offers visa free access to citizens of many countries such as UK, USA etc. If you‚Äôre flying from India, you can get a free visa on arrival if you book hotels on the Discover Qatar website ‚Äì  This is very convenient and takes just minutes upon arrival.

Doha is really well connected by air from major cities in India ‚Äì we‚Äôd suggest booking a flight with Qatar Airways to enjoy the amazing service

Begin your journey at the Mondrian Doha, a five-star fantasyland designed by Dutch designer Marcel Wanders. Known for its bold interiors and art-centric spaces, the hotel makes an immediate impression with its grand staircase, lavish spa, and skyline views. Take a moment to unwind and soak in the blend of whimsical luxury and Arabian opulence.

The best time to visit Qatar is between November and February as these are the coolest months. However summer is not a bad time either as you can avail off-season prices on hotels and flights and many markets and restaurants in Doha have outdoor air-conditioning, so exploring the city is fun despite the high temperatures. Have fun eating, exploring, and make sure you shop loads as Qatar offers tax-free shopping.



Here‚Äôs a day by day guide for an unforgettable 4 day holiday in Qatar

Start your morning at Azure Beach Doha, located on the waterfront at the St. Regis Marsa Arabia Island. This exclusive beach club offers a resort-style vibe with infinity pools, sun loungers, and cabanas‚Äîall set against a pristine backdrop of turquoise Gulf waters. Order a smoothie or fresh seafood platter and let the vacation mindset sink in.

Pro Tip: Bring a swimsuit and sunscreen‚Äîthis spot is photogenic and perfect for laid-back lounging.



After a sunny morning, head to Baron, a bistro nestled in the colourful Mina District. Expect elegantly plated dishes with Middle Eastern flavours. Try their signature drinks or sharing platters ‚Äì this restaurant is on the Michelin Guide 2025 and it is easy to see why!





Next, explore the Mina District, a vibrant neighbourhood within the revitalised Old Doha Port. Colourful buildings, quirky cafes, and artisan shops make this one of Doha‚Äôs most Instagrammable neighbourhoods. It‚Äôs a cultural and architectural feast that combines modern flair with Gulf heritage.



As golden hour approaches, board a dhow cruise‚Äîa traditional Qatari wooden boat. Drift across the bay while taking in panoramic views of the West Bay skyline. Many cruises offer onboard tea and dates, adding to the ambience. Tickets cost around INR 500 per person, and it‚Äôs the best way to enjoy a beautiful sunset.



Return to The Pearl-Qatar to admire the Hamad bin Jassim Mosque, known for its minimalistic yet grand architectural design. Continue to the newly developed Gewan Island, a futuristic waterfront extension of The Pearl featuring fine dining, luxury boutiques, and marina views. Our favourite experience here was the Crystal Walk ‚Äì walking through a marketplace with outdoor air-conditioning is an experience in itself. But Crystal Walk is home to luxurious cafes, shops, and a light-display that is a joy to experience.



Begin your day with a leisurely breakfast in West Walk, a lifestyle hub in Al Waab known for its open-air design and curated food spots. Whether you‚Äôre into avocado toast, shakshuka, or cold brews, there are plenty of upscale cafes to choose from. We really like Piccolo ‚Äì think avocado toasts, acai bowls, really good coffee and smoothies! The best part is that West Walk is air-conditioned and you can sit outdoors even during peak summer months ‚Äì what a luxury!



Your cultural deep dive begins at the National Museum of Qatar, designed by Jean Nouvel and inspired by the desert rose. The museum walks you through Qatar‚Äôs journey‚Äîfrom Bedouin traditions to modern prosperity‚Äîwith immersive exhibits, audiovisual storytelling, and architecture that rivals any global landmark. The building is iconic from the outside but make sure you spend some time indoors ‚Äì you‚Äôll come back with a new appreciation for Qatari history and culture



Next, head to Place Vend√¥me Mall in Lusail Entertainment City, a Parisian-inspired shopping haven featuring over 500 luxury and mid-range boutiques. With its neoclassical architecture, dancing fountains, and waterfront promenade, it‚Äôs more than a mall‚Äîit‚Äôs a lifestyle destination. Browse fashion houses like Dior, Chanel, and Balmain or relax at one of the high-end caf√©s. Whether you shop or not, make sure you visit Place Vend√¥me to experience everything Doha has to offer



Wrap up the day with dinner at Carbone, located on Al Maha Island, an ultra-exclusive nightlife and leisure destination. The NYC-born restaurant offers decadent Italian-American fare in a Gatsby-esque setting. Food is scrumptious but portions are large, so order with caution. We suggest requesting a table on the outside deck so that you can enjoy beautiful views over sunset



Ease into the day with breakfast at Mondrian‚Äôs CUT by Wolfgang Puck or EllaMia Caf√©. Enjoy Middle Eastern and international dishes in a design-rich atmosphere. Check out of the hotel as you will be spending your final night in a gorgeous hotel just an hour away from Doha

Head to Katara Cultural Village, Doha‚Äôs arts and culture hub. Stroll through galleries, admire public art installations, and explore traditional architecture. Be sure to visit the Katara Mosque, known for its turquoise and gold detailing, and the amphitheater with its sweeping sea views. If you‚Äôre here during summer months, then schedule this visit for the evening, when it‚Äôs cooler.



Right next door is 21 High St., a luxury, air-conditioned (yes you read that right :-)) open-air shopping street featuring brands like Galeries Lafayette and curated boutiques. It‚Äôs a place where haute couture meets ice-sculpture caf√©s and avant-garde architecture. Perfect for a bit of shopping or a stroll



If you‚Äôd like yet more shopping, drive over to Al Hazm, a luxurious shopping mall that blends Italian marble with Qatari splendor. With its colonnades, glass domes, and indoor gardens, it feels more like a European palace than a shopping mall. Sip on saffron coffee or browse exclusive designer brands. If you‚Äôre an F1 fan, it is also home to the iconic Mc Laren caf√©, the first of its kind.



If time allows, take a walk through Msheireb Downtown, a smart city development that redefines modern Gulf architecture with sustainability and heritage in mind. Expect to find cafes, galleries, and museums dot the area before checking out of your hotel and beginning the drive to Ras Abrouq to catch sunset in the desert



Start your drive from Doha and catch sunset en-route in Zekreet -home to a traditional Arabic village and limestone formations that make sunset spectacular

Only 1.5 hours from Doha lies Our Habitas Ras Abrouq, an eco-luxury resort nestled along the wild, lunar-like landscapes of the Qatari desert near the UNESCO-listed Zekreet Peninsula. Enjoy yoga, mindful meals, and outdoor lounging with views of rock formations and the Arabian Gulf. The best part ‚Äì the star-laden night sky and the sheer silence of the countryside. We strongly suggest spending a night here.

Spend your morning at Our Habitas Ras Abrouq ‚Äì enjoy the hotel‚Äôs iconic pool, savour the food which prides itself on being a combination of Mexican, Indian, and Middle-Eastern flavours, and the quiet surroundings. This is a true desert escape.

Once you check-out, start your 1.5 hour drive back to Doha.



Return to Doha in the late afternoon and immerse yourself in Souq Waqif, the city‚Äôs historic marketplace. Lose yourself in a maze of spice stalls, fabric shops, and artisanal wares. Pick up oud perfume, pashmina scarves, or handcrafted souvenirs for friends and family back home.



End your Doha adventure with dinner at Parisa, a Persian restaurant within the Souq. Its mirrored mosaics, hand-painted ceilings, and chandeliers transport you to another world, while the menu serves rich dishes like kebabs, stews, and saffron rice. It‚Äôs best to reserve a table here beforehand as the place gets really busy in the evenings



This is the official end of your Doha escape  as you depart from Hamad International Airport. Ranked one of the best airports in the world, HIA offers a seamless travel experience with designer boutiques, art installations, and exceptional lounges. Don‚Äôt forget to shop a bit before boarding your flight back home.

In this 4-day Qatar itinerary we tried to balance coastal leisure, cultural richness, shopping, and dining. Whether you‚Äôre looking for a romantic getaway, a cultural deep-dive, or a luxe escape, Doha delivers an experience that‚Äôs both opulent and authentic. From dhow cruises to desert meditations, this will allow you to immerse yourself in the best the Qatari capital has to offer. Kyrgyzstan is a breathtaking gem of Central Asia and it used to be a vital stop on the Silk Road. If you‚Äôre travelling from India, it is ideal for travellers who have a week to spare and are seeking raw natural beauty, rich nomadic culture, and off-the-beaten-path adventures. It is often known as the ‚ÄúSwitzerland of Central Asia‚Äù and with good reason. Expect towering mountain ranges, lush valleys, and pristine alpine lakes

Over 90% of the country is covered by mountains ‚Äì this means dramatic landscapes perfect for trekking, horseback riding, and camping in yurts. The crown jewel of Kyrgyzstan‚Äôs natural wonders is Issyk-Kul Lake, the world‚Äôs second-largest alpine lake. Other must-visit destinations include the rugged beauty of Ala Archa National Park, the surreal red rock formations of Jeti-√ñg√ºz, and the untouched wilderness of Song-Kul Lake, where travelers can experience authentic nomadic life. Kyrgyzstan is one of the few countries that have retained its nomadic traditions, with locals still practicing eagle hunting, felt-making, and yurt-building

Here is everything you need to know before you visit Kyrgyzstan ‚Äì this itinerary provides the perfect combination of adventure, history, and culture Whether hiking through remote valleys, exploring ancient Silk Road relics, or simply sharing tea with nomads under a starry sky, a journey through Kyrgyzstan promises an unforgettable experience.

Here‚Äôs a detailed 5 to 6 day road trip itinerary for Kyrgyzstan, covering Bishkek, Issyk-Kul Lake, Ala Archa National Park, and Karakol

Aero Nomad offers direct flights from Delhi to Bishkek. However these don‚Äôt often show up on search engines, so you will need to book directly from their website. Our return flights cost approximately INR 40,000 ($500) per person. Alternatively you can take an indirect flight with Air Astana which is also cheaper.

Kyrgyzstan is visa-free for 7days if you have a valid, multiple-entry UK, USA, or Schengen visa (Please read details here). If not, you can apply for an e-visa to visit Kyrgyzstan, the details for which can be found here: Kyrgystan E-visa official. Please keep in mind that you‚Äôll need a Letter of Invitation from a Kyrgyz travel agent or a Kyrgyz national (see details below)

Download the Google Translate App and the Yandex App before you travel to Kyrgyzstan. Uber doesn‚Äôt work there and you can use Yandex to conveniently book cabs in bigger cities. English is understood only in big cities, so you will definitely need Google Translate for your one week trip in Kyrgyzstan.

We booked all our day trips and excursions in Kyrgyzstan with Visit Bishkek ‚Äì you can Whatsapp them on the number +996 707 727 888 ‚Äì they can also arrange an invitation letter for your visa at a cost, even if you are not booking travels with them. We found out about this tour provider from a friend and they were super safe and reliable!

Spend a day in Bishkek, the vibrant capital of Kyrgyzstan. Sheraton Bishkek and Novotel Bishkek City Centre are both good hotels and conveniently located to explore the city. We suggest choosing a nice and comfortable hotel in Bishkek as you will find only basic amenities once you head to the countryside on days 2 and 3.

Rest well and spend a day exploring Bishkek. Start your morning at Ala-Too Square, the heart of the city. Take some photos at the impressive Manas Statue, a tribute to the country‚Äôs legendary hero, and, if you‚Äôre lucky, witness the hourly changing of the guards. From here, a short walk will bring you to the ‚ÄúRussian Church‚Äù (you can put it on google maps) ‚Äì it‚Äôs a quiet and beautiful structure in the midst of the city‚Äôs commotion ‚Äì ideal if you enjoy city architecture photography.

From there, head to the bustling Osh Bazaar, one of Central Asia‚Äôs most authentic markets. Wander through the colourful stalls filled with fragrant spices, fresh produce, dried fruits, and traditional kurut (dried yogurt balls). This is also a great place to pick up handmade souvenirs for your house, such as felt carpets and traditional Kyrgyz hats (kalpaks).

For lunch, head to Navat, a cozy restaurant offering an authentic Central Asian dining experience. Try beshbarmak (noodles with meat), lagman (hand-pulled noodles), or manty (steamed dumplings), all served in a beautifully decorated setting with traditional Kyrgyz elements.

After lunch, visit the stunning Blue Mosque (Central Mosque of Imam Sarakhsi), an architectural masterpiece blending Ottoman and Central Asian influences. Make sure you include this as its intricate blue tile-work and peaceful ambiance makes it an under-rated gem in Bishkek.

Continue your exploration with a leisurely walk through Oak Park & Erkindik Boulevard, a green oasis in the city. The park is home to Soviet-era sculptures, outdoor caf√©s, and tree-lined paths perfect for relaxing. Erkindik Boulevard, a pedestrian-friendly street, is ideal for soaking in the city‚Äôs lively atmosphere.

End your day at a caf√© along Erkindik, sipping tea or Kyrgyz coffee while reflecting on Bishkek‚Äôs unique mix of history, culture, and modern charm.



Leave for a 2 day trip to the South Shore of Issyk-kul Lake. We suggest booking a private car with driver for this. This 2 day trip costs approximately $650 including car, accommodation, and meals and we booked it with Visit Bishkek as previously mentioned.

Start your trip early, driving 1.5 hours from Bishkek to the Burana Tower, a 10th-century minaret and a remnant of the ancient Silk Road city of Balasagun. Climb the tower for panoramic views and explore the surrounding balbal (stone warrior statues) that date back to the Turkic era.

Next, continue to Aksai Canyon, a hidden gem with dramatic red rock formations. Take a short hike to enjoy breathtaking views over the rugged landscapes. The canyon is much less visited than other sites, so you might not see many people around. A 4√ó4 is recommended for this üôÇ

In the afternoon, arrive at the south shore of Issyk-Kul Lake, where you can experience a traditional yurt stay. This is the more scenic shore of the lake, so it‚Äôs the ideal place to spend a night! Enjoy a delicious Kyrgyz meal, relax by the lake, and take in the stunning sunset over the Terskey Alatau mountains. In the evening, sit by the fire, listen to local legends, and gaze at the star-filled sky.





Wake up early for a short drive to Fairytale (Skazka) Canyon, named for its surreal, multi-colored rock formations that resemble castles, animals, and mystical creatures. Hike through the otherworldly landscape, exploring the deep red and orange cliffs shaped by wind and water over centuries.

After the hike, we suggest driving further towards Barskoon Waterfalls, in the Jeti-√ñg√ºz district ‚Äì     it‚Äôs a beautiful drive through lush green mountains, and the multi-tiered falls are worth hiking for.  From here you can continue onto Karakol or head back to Bishkek, arriving by early evening. This two-day adventure offers a perfect mix of history, nature, and nomadic culture, making it an unforgettable Kyrgyz experience.

I used to think ‚Äúhome‚Äù was a dirty word. Out there ‚Äî on the road ‚Äî was where life happened, full of exciting adventures, fascinating people, and endless possibilities. No dreary commutes, 30-minute lunch breaks, mind-numbing meetings, or endless lists of to-dos squeezed into a rushed weekend.

Why would anyone want to be home, the place where routine seemed to sap your will to exist? It baffled me.

My first trip overseas ‚Äî a vacation to Costa Rica ‚Äî made me fall in love with travel. For all the reasons mentioned above, I realized why ‚Äúvacations‚Äù were so romanticized in work culture. There was a freedom to them that stood in stark contrast to the daily corporate grind.

So, when I finally quit my job, I set off on an adventure to experience all the world had to offer for as long as I could make my money last.

I mean, who could possibly tire of life on the road?

Well, me.

Eventually, I did tire of being a full-time nomad. I craved a stable group of friends, regular workouts, a bar that knew my name, a kitchen to cook in, and my own bed.

Suddenly, I realized that ‚Äúhome‚Äù wasn‚Äôt a dirty word. It just felt that way to a young, restless soul for whom adulthood felt eons away.

I had come to understand what someone who is just setting out with romantic notions about travel couldn‚Äôt: You can burn out. On my first trip abroad, after 18 months, I hit the wall and decided to cut my trip short. Then, years later, in 2013, I decided that being a nomad was no longer the life for me and decided to stop traveling full-time.

It was time to grow up, I said. Time to stay put and move on from nomad to‚Ä¶ whatever came next.

But the allure of the road ‚Äî and the business of working in travel ‚Äî pulled me back constantly.

As the years went by, I lived between two worlds: one in which I am traveling, longing for home, and another in which I am home, longing to head out again.

There were moments where I longed for a clone so I could live in both and satisfy my dual desires.

After all, you can‚Äôt ‚Äî and shouldn‚Äôt ‚Äî live solely in one forever.

Because travel and home are complementary forces, yin and yang. Without one, you can‚Äôt appreciate the other.

All travelers hit a wall, that moment when they look around and go, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm ready to stay in one place.‚Äù When and why that happens is a product of many factors, but I have yet to meet a traveler who doesn‚Äôt have that experience. When I started traveling in my twenties, it took me years to feel that. But now, a couple of decades older, it happens after just a month.

To handle life, the brain creates mental shortcuts to help it process information. It‚Äôs why we tend to drive the same route to work every day ‚Äî it‚Äôs just easier, and it‚Äôs why you feel like ‚Äúyou can do it in your sleep.‚Äù Because if your brain had to figure out a new route to work every day, it would tire itself out. These routines let us put a lot of life on autopilot, so we have energy for work, people, emotions, thoughts, etc.

But when you travel, you are relearning life skills every day. You have no mental shortcuts. It takes a lot of mental energy to figure out your way in the world anew each day, to repack your bag, say good-bye to the person you met yesterday, and head out and try again to navigate unfamiliar lands, languages, and people as if you had never done so before.
